explosives.rationale: Classification not possible, because of lack of data (though the substance contains chemical groups associated with explosive properties that contain nitrogen but lack oxygen). Classified into Class 3, Division 6.1 and Class 8 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#2029)

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is 38degC (c.c.) (ICSC, 1999), which is classified into Category 3. Classified into Class 3, Division 6.1 and Class 8 (UN#2029) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: The substance contains nitrogen atoms adjacent to each other. Classified into Class 3, Division 6.1 and Class 8 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#2029)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classification not possible, due to lack of data, though the substance is considered "pyrophoric" under certain conditions, with its flash point ranging from 24degC (rusty iron surface) to 270degC (glass surface).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing no oxygen and halogen

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Corrosivity to metals remains uncertain, though classified as "corrosive substances" (as the classification based on UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods includes "skin corrosivity") (UN#2029).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) of 60 mg/kg (DFGOT vol.1 (1989)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the testing data of rabbit LD50 (dermal route) of 91 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 (4 hours) value of 570ppm, calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 0.75 mg/L (4 hours) (DFGOT vol.1 (1989)), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (21,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 2.1kPa (20degC) (CERI Hazard Data 97-15 (1998)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Due to lack of data for subclassification, though the results of rabbit skin irritation tests suggest irritating reaction, with fatal cases reported in some subjects, although the substance should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "severe irritation" from rabbit eye irritation tests.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the classification by the Japan Society for Occupational Health (2004).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests in mouse red blood) and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.73 (2004).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as 2B by IARC (1999), Category A3 by ACGIH (2005), Category B2 by IRIS (2005) and Category R by NTP (2005).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.73 (2004): the results of mouse developmental toxicity studies suggest exencephalia in offspring at dose levels toxic to parent animals.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (nervous system, liver) May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "confusion, lethargy, restlessness," "loss of consciousness, erubescence, irregular violent behavior followed by ataxia," "nystagmus, a decrease in vibration sensation, prickling in the arm and leg," "an increase in AST/LDH/ total bilirubin levels" (EHC 68 (1987)), and "a significant increase in the oxygen value associated with liver toxicity" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.73 (2003)).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.classification: Category 1 (liver, respiratory system, kidney, adrenal gland)
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, respiratory system, kidney, adrenal gland)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on human evidence including "jaundice, pneumonia, an increase in creatinine concentrations, albuminuria, hematuria, hepatocellular necrosis, nephritis, renal tubule necrosis, glomerulonephritis" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.73 (2003)), "pleural effusion and shadow (pulmonary x-ray findings), an increase in blood bilirubin levels, pneumonia (observed in autopsy cases), damage to hepatocytes" (EHC 68 (1987)), and the evidence from animal studies including "bile duct hyperplasia, degeneration of the adrenal, nasal mucosal inflammation, necrosis of the nasal mucosal epithelium and scale formation, hyperplasia, squamous epithelium metaplasia" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.73 (2003)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours EC50=160microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 1, 2002).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (log Kow=-2.07(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 2%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 1.
